subject: RE: [junit] Testing memory usage
msgSnippet: ... Creating these objects statically might give you a wrong answer:  at runtime, the objects might actually be subclasses of their effective type, which will
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of twall

> The following class does a "sizeof" calculation given either
> a class with no-args ctor or an object which creates
> instances of the desired class:

Creating these objects statically might give you a wrong answer: at
runtime, the objects might actually be subclasses of their effective type,
which will most likely be bigger than the ones you are measuring.

Also, another method than the one you are using could be to add up the sizes
of the fields of your class recursively.

--
